questions.text: What is the Lancefield grouping of β-hemolytic-streptococci based on?
questions.solution:
Lancefield grouping of β-hemolytic-streptococci is based on group-specific carbohydrate C antigen present on the cell wall. He classified them into 20 serological types from Group-A to Group V except for I and J.

Group A β-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are further classified by Griffith typing based on protein antigens (M, T, R) present on the cell surface.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic lady presented with swelling and pain of her right leg following a skin biopsy. She was febrile at the time of examination and hemorrhagic bullae with necrosis of the surrounding skin were noted on her leg. Gram staining of the pus collected from the bullae is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus).

Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive inflammatory infection of the fascia, with secondary necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues. It has also been referred to as Meleney ulcer, acute dermal gangrene, hospital gangrene, suppurative fasciitis, and synergistic necrotizing cellulitis. The source of the infection is either the skin, with organisms introduced into the tissue through trauma, or the bowel flora, with organisms released during abdominal surgery.

The onset of symptoms is usually quite acute and is marked by severe pain at the site of involvement, malaise, fever, chills, and a toxic appearance. The affected limb is edematous with the overlying skin turning dusky with mottled erythema and the development of hemorrhagic bullae.

This is a surgical emergency as the condition is rapidly fatal. Treatment of the condition includes:

  • Surgical intervention is the major therapeutic modality in cases of necrotizing fasciitis.
  • Antibiotics- penicillin (1-4 million U IV q4h) plus clindamycin (600-900 mg IV q8h).

The following image shows surgical debridement being done for a case of necrotising fasciitis.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought in by her mother to the OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat, and a scarlatiniform rash. A throat swab was taken and sent to the lab for culture on blood agar. Which of the following factors is responsible for the zones of hemolysis seen in the culture below?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario o a patient with fever, sore throat, and a scarlatiniform rash is suggestive of scarlet fever caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. Streptolysin S is the factor responsible for the zones of hemolysis seen around streptococcal colonies on blood agar.

Streptococci produces two hemolysins:

  • Streptolysin O is called so because it is oxygen-labile. It is also heat-labile and it has specific cardiotoxic and leucotoxic activity.
  • Streptolysin S is called so because it is soluble in serum. It is also oxygen-stable hemolysin. It is a protein but is not antigenic.

The following image shows blood agar with colonies of streptococci with hemolytic zones around them:

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), which is a superantigen.

Superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and Vβ region of the TCR. Some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin.

The below image shows the binding of superantigen to T-cell receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following types of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins is bacteriophage mediated?
questions.solution:
Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins type A and type C are bacteriophage-mediated toxins.

The streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin(SPE) is so named because the primary effect of the toxin is the induction of fever. It is also known as erythrogenic toxin because its intra-dermal injection into susceptible individuals produced an erythematous reaction (Dick Test).

There are 3 types of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins namely:

  • type A - phage mediated.
  • type B - chromosome mediated.
  • type C - phage mediated.

Related Pearl: Toxins that are coded by phage DNA - Mnemonic

A: Group A strep (S. pyogenes): pyrogenic exotoxins SpeA and SpeC

B: Botulinum toxin C & D

C: Cholera toxin

D: Diphtheria toxin

E: E.coli(EHEC): Verocytotoxin (Shiga-like toxin)

questions.text: Which of the following is a streptococcal toxin responsible for connective tissue breakdown?
questions.solution:
Hyaluronidase is the streptococcal toxin responsible for connective tissue breakdown.

Hyaluronidase or spreading factor is expressed by non-capsulated strains of Streptococcus pyogenes, such as M type 4 and 22. It acts by cleaving hyaluronic acid, which is present in the connective tissue, epithelial, and neural tissues. This results in the spread of infection along the intercellular space.

questions.text: Which streptococcal antigen cross reacts with myocardium?
questions.solution:
Antibodies to the cell wall M antigen present on the Streptococcus cross-reacts with a similar myocardial antigen. This cross-reaction with myocardium is the cause of acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with a sore throat for 3 days. Which of the following medium is used to culture the throat swab?
questions.solution:
Blood agar is the preferred culture media as it is used for the culture and isolation of Streptococcus pyogenes which is the most common cause of sore throat.

The selective medium for Streptococcus pyogenes is Crystal violet blood agar and the transport media for this organism is Pikes medium.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms show beta-hemolysis on blood agar, resistance to bacitracin, and a positive CAMP test?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B streptococci that shows β-hemolysis on blood agar, is resistant to bacitracin, and gives a positive CAMP test.

The CAMP test is used to identify group B β-hemolyitic-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor. This factor causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed by Staphylococcus aureus, when Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a streak of Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar. This produces the characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis.

The below image shows a positive CAMP test. 

The following table provides important laboratory characteristics which differentiate Streptococcus pyogenes from Streptococcus agalactiae.

S.agalactiae B β Bacitracin resistant, PYR test negative, Hippurate hydrolysis positive, CAMP test positive

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with an infective skin lesion over his leg. On microscopic examination of the pus from the lesion, gram-positive cocci in chains are visualized and pus culture shows β-haemolytic colonies on blood agar. Which of the following tests can be performed to identify the causative organism?
questions.solution:
β hemolytic colonies on blood agar with gram-positive cocci in chains seen on microscopy suggest the organism is a β-hemolytic streptococcus. Bacitracin sensitivity is used to differentiate between group A and group B β-hemolytic streptococci. 

Group A: Bacitracin-sensitive (S. pyogenes)

Group B: Bacitracin-resistant (S. agalactiae)

Options A & B: Bile solubility and optochin sensitivity are used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci. They are both α hemolytic on blood agar but some species of viridans streptocci are non hemolytic. 

Option D: Catalase test is used to differentiate streptococcus and staphylococcus. Staphylococcus appear as clusters of gram positive cocci on microscopy and not chains.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is associated with the causation of colorectal carcinoma, rectal polyp, endocarditis and septicaemia and is pyrrolidinyl arylamidase test negative?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus gallolyticus is associated with the causation of colorectal CA, rectal polyp, endocarditis, and septicemia and is pyrrolidinyl arylamidase test (PYR test) negative.

Streptococcus gallolyticus, formerly called Streptococcus bovis, is a non-enterococcal Group D streptococci. It is bile insoluble, esculin hydrolysis positive, PYR negative and shows no growth in 6.5% NaCl.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can survive up to 60°C, is PYR positive, and can grow on media with  6.5% NaCl?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Enterococcus feacalis can survive up to 60°C, is PYR test positive, and can grow in the presence of 6.5% NaCl.

Enterococci have the following features:

  • Formation of tiny deep pink colonies on MacConkey’s medium
  • Survives at 600C for 30 minutes.
  • Growth in the presence of 40 % bile, 6.5% sodium chloride at pH 9.6.
  • PYR (Pyrrolidonyl Arylamidase) positive
  • Esculin hydrolysis is positive.
  • Usually nonhemolytic, but may show α or β hemolysis.

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes is a delicate organism, easily destroyed by heat (54°C for 30 min), PYR positive.

Option B: Streptococcus agalactiae is PYR test negative.

Option D: Streptococcus pneumoniae are readily destroyed by heat (52°C for 15 min).

questions.text: A patient admitted to an ICU spiked a fever and his blood culture was positive for gram-positive cocci in chains, which are catalase-negative. He was being given ceftazidime and amikacin via a central venous line for the past week. Following this, you started him on vancomycin but his blood culture remained positive for the same organism even after 2 weeks of therapy. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing the infection?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) infection.

Gram-positive cocci in chains that are catalase-negative suggest that the organism belongs to Streptococcaceae family. Positive culture after 2 weeks of vancomycin therapy suggests resistance to vancomycin.

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes are sensitive to vancomycin and are not commonly implicated in central venous line infections.

Option B: Viridans streptococci are usually mouth commensals and are sensitive to vancomycin.

Option D: Coagulase-negative staphylococci are gram-positive cocci in clusters which are catalase-positive. Hence, they can be ruled out.

questions.text: Oral examination of a young patient shows the following finding. Which bacteria belonging to viridans group is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows dental caries which are commonly caused by Streptococcus mutans. It belongs to the viridans group/α-hemolytic streptococci.

Streptococcus mutans breaks down the dietary sucrose producing acid and a tough adhesive dextran. The acid damages dentine while the dextrans bind together with food debris, epithelial cells, mucus, and bacteria to form dental plaques, leading to formation of dental caries.

questions.text: Quellung reaction is used to demonstrate_______.
questions.solution:
Quellung reaction is used to demonstrate the capsule of streptococci.

Quellung reaction (Quellung = swelling):

  • A suspension of pneumococci is mixed on a slide with a drop of type-specific antiserum and a loop full of methylene blue solution.
  • In the presence of homologous antiserum, the capsule becomes apparently swollen, sharply delineated and refractile.
  • The Quellung test can be done directly with sputum from acute pneumonia cases.

The below image shows the swollen capsule of pneumococci following the addition of homologous antiserum.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for the draughtsman appearance of pneumococcal colonies?
questions.solution:
The factor responsible for the draughtsman appearance of pneumococcal colonies is autolysin.

When pneumococci are incubated on blood agar for a prolonged duration, the resultant colonies are surrounded with concentric rings and have a central umbonation. This appearance of pneumococcal colonies is known as carrom coin appearance or draughtsman appearance.

Autolysin is an amidase enzyme produced by pneumococci that cleaves peptidoglycan, leading to the autolysis of cells. It is also responsible for the bile solubility of pneumococci.

The below image shows the characteristic draughtsman appearance of pneumococcal colonies.

questions.text: In a splenectomized patient, there is an increased risk of infection by all capsulated organisms. Which of the following is least likely to cause an infection in such patients?
questions.solution:
In splenectomized patients, there is an increased risk of infection by capsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. Staphylococcus aureus does not have a capsule and so poses no increased risk to these individuals.

The phagocytosis of capsulated organisms is prevented by their capsule. Thus, the body's main defence against these organisms is the spleen.

Certain components called opsonins attach to these capsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pneumococcal vaccine?

choices.text: Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine PPSV23 is indicated in splenectomized patients.
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine  PCV13  is contraindicated in children less than 2 years.
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine PPV 23 gives protection for 10 years.
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine is contraindicated if age > 65 years.

questions.solution:
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine PPSV23 is indicated in splenectomised patients.

There are two kinds of polyvalent pneumococcal vaccines:

  1. Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23
    • It is indicated in splenectomized patients, sickle cell disease, immunocompromised patients, and patients above 65 years of age. 
    • CDC currently recommends the administration of one additional dose of PPSV23 at least 5 years after the last dose.
    • Children younger than 2 years old should not get this vaccine since they fail to mount an adequate response.
  2. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine-
    • It includes PCV10 and PCV13.
    • It is indicated in children less than 2 years.

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.
